message_1: Using natural deduction, prove that the formula [(p → q) ∧ (q → r)] → (p → r) is a tautology.
message_2:
To prove that the formula [(p → q) ∧ (q → r)] → (p → r) is a tautology using natural deduction, we will assume the antecedent [(p → q) ∧ (q → r)] and show that the consequent (p → r) follows. Here's the proof:

1. (p → q) ∧ (q → r) (Assumption)
2. p → q (1, ∧-Elimination)
3. q → r (1, ∧-Elimination)
4. p (Assumption)
5. q (2, 4, →-Elimination)
6. r (3, 5, →-Elimination)
7. p → r (4-6, →-Introduction)
8. [(p → q) ∧ (q → r)] → (p → r) (1-7, →-Introduction)

Thus, the formula [(p → q) ∧ (q → r)] → (p → r) is a tautology, as we have shown that assuming the antecedent leads to the consequent using natural deduction rules.
